p.s: Fibrotic thickening of the peritoneum develops in patients receiving peritoneal dialysis (PD) for renal failure.
For unknown reasons, however, in some patients it progresses to extensive fibrosis that compromises dialysis capacity of the peritoneum.
It is increasingly clear that fibroblasts display large heterogeneity not only between but also within tissues.
Differential surface expression of thymocyte differentiation antigen 1 (Thy-1) has been shown to identify functionally distinct fibroblast subsets in several organs.
Here, we isolated Thy-1 ϩ/Ϫ subsets of human peritoneal fibroblasts (HPFB) and analyzed them in terms of profibrotic myofibroblast features.
In healthy individuals, Thy-1 ϩ cells constituted ~45% of the HPFB population found in the greater omentum but were not detected in the parietal peritoneum.

When propagated in culture and compared with Thy-1 Ϫ cells, omentumderived Thy-1 ϩ HPFB consistently displayed an increased expression of ␣-smooth muscle actin, collagen I, and transforming growth factor-␤1.
They also showed greater proliferation capacity and enhanced contractile properties.
The number of Thy-1 ϩ HPFB increased significantly in PD patients and made up more than 70 and 95% of all HPFB found in the omentum and parietal peritoneum, respectively.
These data indicate that the expansion of Thy-1 ϩ fibroblasts may contribute to fibrotic thickening of the peritoneal membrane during PD.

fibrosis; myofibroblasts; peritoneal dialysis; peritoneal fibroblasts; thymocyte differentiation antigen 1 FIBROTIC THICKENING of the peritoneum develops typically in patients treated with peritoneal dialysis (PD) for kidney failure (25).
However, it is unclear why only in some patients this process progresses to extensive fibrosis/sclerosis that results in technique failure.
Myofibroblasts are key effector cells in peritoneal fibrosis, but their origin is still debated (19).
Recent lineage-tracing experiments point to resident peritoneal fibroblasts as the main source of myofibroblasts (4).
It is recognized that resident fibroblasts display large heterogeneity and differ not only between the tissues or anatomical locations but also within the same organs.
fibroblast subsets is the presence of the surface thymocyte differentiation antigen 1 [Thy-1; cluster of differentiation 90 (CD90)], a glycophosphatidylinositol-linked outer membrane protein.
Fibroblasts that differ in Thy-1 expression have different capacity for producing extracellular matrix proteins (5) and expressing growth factor receptors (7).
Interestingly, Thy-1 expression appears to determine fibroblast properties in a tissue-specific manner, so that Thy-1 ϩ and Thy-1 Ϫ subsets may play different roles in different tissues (2,6,24).
In the present study we explored the existence of Thy-1 ϩ/Ϫ fibroblasts in the human peritoneum and determined their propensity to differentiate into myofibroblasts.
Isolation and culture of human peritoneal fibroblasts.
Cells were isolated from specimens of normal omentum obtained from consenting patients undergoing elective abdominal surgery.
The use of fragments of omentum discarded during surgery for peritoneal cell isolation was approved by the institutional ethics committee (decision no.
The isolation technique was modified from the protocols described previously by Jörres et al. (10) and Kenny et al. (13).
Briefly, the tissue was collected, washed in PBS, and then exposed sequentially to four rounds of enzymatic digestion at 37°C.
Initially, it was treated with two 30-min rounds of digestion with trypsin-EDTA (0.05%-0.02%;

Biochrom, Berlin, Germany) and then with two 60-min rounds of digestion with collagenase type I (from Clostridium histolyticum, 1 mg/ml; Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) and hyaluronidase (0.1 mg/ml; Sigma-Aldrich).

Human peritoneal fibroblasts (HPFB) released after the last round of digestion were suspended and propagated in fibroblast medium supplemented with penicillin (100 U/ml), streptomycin (100 g/ml), fibroblast growth supplement, and 2% (vol/vol) fetal bovine serum (FBS; all from ScienCell, Carlsbad, CA).
The cells were not specifically tested for the presence of mycoplasma.
Purification of HPFB subsets.

As HPFB obtained by the above procedure may be occasionally contaminated with mesothelial and/or endothelial cells (26), they were further purified by magnetic-activated cell sorting (MACS; Miltenyi Biotec, Bergisch Gladbach, Germany), as per the manufacturer's instructions.
Briefly, cells were suspended in PBS with 0.5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) and 2 mM EDTA, pH 7.2, and incubated at ambient temperature with Anti-Fibroblast MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec) for 30 min.
The cells were then washed, loaded onto a column, and placed in magnetic field.
The retained fibroblasts were eluted, collected, and cultured in fibroblast medium.

Their identity was confirmed by positive immunostaining for fibroblast-specific protein-1 (FSP1) and negative immunostaining for biomarkers of mesothelial and endothelial cells, as previously de-scribed (3).
Fibroblasts thus obtained were further separated by MACS technology into Thy-1 ϩ and Thy-1 Ϫ fractions using CD90 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec).
The purity of positively and negatively selected cells was confirmed by immunofluorescent staining and flow cytometry (Fig. 1).
Immunostaining.

Cells were grown on Lab-Tek chamber slides (Nunc, Langenselbold, Germany), fixed in 3.7% paraformaldehyde, permeabilized with 0.1% Triton X-100, blocked with 5% BSA, and incubated with primary antibodies for 1 h at 37°C (see Table 1 for details of all antibodies used throughout the study).

The slides were then incubated with appropriate fluorescent Alexa dye-labeled secondary antibodies in PBS and counterstained with 4=,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) nuclear stain (all from Invitrogen/Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA).

Positively stained cells were counted in five randomly selected fields under a fluorescence microscope (Keyence BZ-X700; Osaka, Japan) at ϫ200 magnification and expressed as a percentage of the total number of DAPI-stained nuclei.
Flow cytometry.

One million cells from each subset were washed, suspended in 100-l cell staining buffer (BioLegend, San Diego, CA), and stained with either FITC-conjugated anti-CD90 or isotype control IgG (BioLegend) for 30 min at 4°C.
Then cells were washed and analyzed using BD FACSAria III cell sorter and FACSDiva software (Becton Dickinson, Oxford, United Kingdom).
Western blotting.

Cells were washed twice with ice-cold HEPES-NaCl buffer (10 mM-150 mM, pH 7.5) and lysed on ice for 10 min with lysis buffer (20 mM Tris, pH 8; 138 mM NaCl; 10% glycerol; 4 mM EDTA; and 1% Triton X-100) supplemented with proteasephosphatase inhibitor cocktail (Roche Applied Science, Indianapolis, IN).
The lysates were centrifuged and the supernatants were collected and analyzed for protein concentration with the Bradford protein assay (Bio-Rad, Munich, Germany).

Equal amounts of protein extracts were separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and then Western blotted using nitrocellulose membranes (Hybond-ECL; Amersham Biosciences, Freiburg, Germany) and appropriate primary and secondary antibodies.
The bands were visualized by chemiluminescence using an enhanced chemiluminescence detection system (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and analyzed using ImageJ v.1.43
software (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD).
Gene expression analysis.
The expression of target genes was assessed with reverse transcription and quantitative PCR.

Total RNA was extracted with RNA Bee (Tel-Test, Friendswood, TX), purified with the RNeasy kit (Qiagen, Hamburg, Germany), and quantified and reverse transcribed into cDNA with a reverse transcription kit (Applied Biosystems, Darmstadt, Germany), as described (11).
Real-time quantitative PCR was performed on the Applied Biosystems 7500 Fast Real-Time PCR system.

The reaction was performed in 14-l reaction volumes containing 2 l of cDNA (20 ng), specific sense and antisense primers (250 nM each), and 7 l of Power SYBR Green PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems).
PCR primers were synthesized by TIB Molbiol (Berlin, Germany), and their sequences are given in Table 2.
After an initial activation step for 2 min at 50°C and denaturation at 95°C for 10 min, 40 cycles of 15 s at 95°C and 1 min at 60°C were performed.
Specificity of the reaction was verified by melting-curve analysis at the end of each series of assays.

The relative amount of gene transcript was calculated by the cycle threshold method using Applied Biosystems 7500 System v.1.2.3 software and normalized for the endogenous reference (␤2-microglobulin).
Gel contraction assay.

HPFB were growth arrested by serum deprivation for 48 h to ensure that gel contraction would not be affected by potential differences in cell numbers resulting from different proliferation capacities of HPFB subsets (see below).

Then equal numbers of cells (100,000/ml) were suspended in 2ϫ concentrated medium and mixed (1:1 vol/vol) with collagen solution (Pure-Col bovine collagen solution, type I, 3 mg/ml; Advanced BioMatrix, Carlsbad, CA) and 0.02 M HEPES.
The gels were placed in culture wells precoated with 2% BSA in PBS and allowed to polymerize for 1 h.
Thereafter the gels were released and left free-floating for contraction for 24 h.
Subsequently, they were photographed and analyzed for size using ImageJ software.
Proliferation assays.
Proliferating cells were visualized by 5-ethynyl-2=-deoxyuridine (EdU) incorporation.
Briefly, HPFB were seeded onto 8-chamber Lab-Tek slides (Nunc) at a density of 5,000 cells per well and quenched with 0.1% FBS for 48 h.
Then, the cells were exposed for 24 h to standard culture medium supplemented with 10 M EdU.
Incorporated EdU was visualized using Click-iT EdU Imaging Kit (Life Technologies/Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA), as per the manufacturer's instructions.
In addition, HPFB proliferation capacity was assessed by 3-[4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl]-2,5-diphenyltetrazolinum bromide (MTT) conversion assay, essentially as described previously (16).
Peritoneal biopsies.
Biopsy samples were obtained from the International Pediatric Peritoneal Biopsy Registry (http://www.pedpd.org/),
which collects specimens of parietal peritoneum and omentum from children undergoing PD.
The study has been registered in the Clinical Trials database (https://clinicaltrials.gov/) under NCT01893710.

The peritoneal biopsies were collected from 1) control patients, who underwent surgery for incidental conditions not affecting the peritoneum; 2) uremic patients, who donated the tissue at the time of PD catheter insertion; and 3) PD patients, who underwent surgery at various times on PD for kidney transplantation or for a PD-related problem (catheter repositioning or removal).
Age of the donors did not differ between the groups and was [median (interquartile range)] 8.7 (4.3-13.6),
7.9 (3.8 -17.1), and 9.6 (5.4 -13.4) yr for controls, uremic patients, and PD patients, respectively (P ϭ 0.94).
Samples were collected in a standardized manner as previously described (25).
Immunostaining was performed on formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded samples according to standard methods.

Briefly, dewaxed and rehydrated 3-m-thick tissue sections were treated with antigen retrieval solution (DakoCytomation, Glostrup, Denmark), blocked with human IgG in 50 mM NH4Cl in PBS, and then treated with primary and secondary antibodies listed in Table 1.
Cell nuclei were counterstained with DAPI (Invitrogen).

The number of cells double staining for FSP1 and Thy-1 was counted in five randomly selected fields under a fluorescence microscope (Leica DM4000 B LED) at ϫ200 magnification and expressed as a percentage of the total number of FSP1 ϩ cells.
The samples were analyzed by two independent observers (E.
Kawka and M. Bartosova) blinded to the history of patients.
Statistics.
Statistical analysis was performed using GraphPad Prism 6.05 software (GraphPad Software, La Jolla, CA).
The data were analyzed with either the t-test or analysis of variance (ANOVA), as appropriate.
A P value Ͻ0.05 was considered significant.

Stepwise enzymatic digestion of normal omentum led to the release of HPFB, whose identity was verified by morphological appearance, immunocytochemical expression of typical fibroblast markers, and the absence of biomarkers of other cell lineages, as described earlier in detail (3).
To ensure the highest purity of the HPFB population, the cells were subjected to MACS with Anti-Fibroblast
MicroBeads.
Positively selected cells immunostained uniformly for FSP1 and were further separated into either Thy-1 Ϫ or Thy-1 ϩ cells.

These HPFB subsets appeared to exist in normal omentum at almost equal proportions, as determined in cells isolated from nine separate donors (56 Ϯ 7 and 44 Ϯ 7% for Thy-1 Ϫ and Thy-1 ϩ , respectively, means Ϯ SE, P ϭ 0.44).
The purity of the subpopulations isolated was 99 Ϯ 1% for Thy-1 ϩ cells and 93 Ϯ 4% for Thy-1 Ϫ cells, as assessed by immunocytochemistry and confirmed by flow cytometry (Fig. 1).
Thy-1 Ϫ and Thy-1 ϩ HPFB differed somewhat in morphology with Thy-1 ϩ cells having a typical fibroblastic spindleshaped appearance and Thy-1 Ϫ fibroblasts being more outspread and irregular.
These features were paralleled with different cytoskeleton organization, as visualized by vimentin immunostaining (Fig. 1).
Expression of myofibroblast markers.
Thy-1 ϩ HPFB displayed an increased expression of ␣-smooth muscle actin (␣-SMA) mRNA and protein (Fig. 2).
The presence of ␣-SMA protein, as detected by immunostaining, was consistently higher in Thy-1 ϩ than in Thy-1 Ϫ cells.

However, the exact numbers of positively stained cells differed between cell lines derived from different donors; a similar pattern was seen in ␣-SMA analysis by immunoblotting and reverse transcription PCR.
Moreover, Thy-1 ϩ HPFB showed increased mRNA expression for collagen I and transforming growth factor-␤1 (TGF-␤1).
By contrast, expression of fibronectin did not differ between the subsets (Fig. 2).
Another feature of myofibroblasts is accelerated proliferation and the presence of contractile properties.
We have thus visualized HPFB proliferation by EdU staining (Fig. 3, A and B).
Incorporation of EdU was detected in 10.3 Ϯ 2.2% of Thy-1 ϩ HPFB compared with 4.7 Ϯ 1.7% of Thy-1 Ϫ HPFB.
Consistently, Thy-1 ϩ HPFB showed greater conversion of the MTT dye compared with Thy-1 Ϫ cells (Fig. 3C).
Furthermore, when embedded into collagen matrices, Thy-1 ϩ HPFB promoted significantly greater gel contraction than Thy-1 Ϫ cells (Fig. 3, D and E).
After 24 h of incubation, the size of gels with embedded Thy-1 ϩ HPFB was smaller by Ͼ10% compared with gels with Thy-1 Ϫ cells.
HPFB subsets in vivo.
Identification of Thy-1 ϩ and Thy-1 Ϫ HPFB in culture led us to examine their presence in an independent set of peritoneal biopsies from the International Pediatric Peritoneal Biopsy Registry.
FSP1 ϩ HPFB were detected in normal omentum, and 45 Ϯ 6% of these cells stained also for Thy-1 (Fig. 4A).
The number of FSP1 ϩ HPFB detected in biopsies from uremic patients was marginally greater, but the proportion of Thy-1 ϩ HPFB was similar to that in the controls.
In contrast, the total number of FSP1 ϩ HPFB and the fraction of Thy-1 ϩ cells (77 Ϯ 4%) were significantly greater in biopsies from patients on PD (Fig. 4C).
Thickness of the submesothelial compact zone in the parietal peritoneum was 150 -400 m in the controls, 50 -300 m in the uremic group, and 100 -650 m in the PD group.

There was no apparent correlation between the presence of Thy-1 ϩ cells and the peritoneal thickness, as well as the average time on PD, the total glucose exposure, and the number of experienced episodes of peritonitis (not shown).

Taking into account topographical diversity and localization memory of fibroblasts, there is an emerging paradigm that fibroblasts for experimental studies should be isolated specifically from the tissue of interest.

Our previous studies with peritoneal fibroblasts have demonstrated that these cells contribute significantly to the peritoneal cytokine network that controls the course of peritoneal inflammation (10,12,27,28).
However, the existence and exact roles of particular peritoneal fibroblast subsets have not been studied to date.
As the presence of cell surface glycoprotein Thy-1 may convey distinct functional features to fibroblasts, we have looked for its expression in peritoneal fibroblasts.
Here, we demonstrate for the first time that there exist fibroblast subpopulations in the human peritoneum that differ in the expression of Thy-1 and profibrotic features.
We have been able to isolate both Thy-1 ϩ and Thy-1 Ϫ fibroblasts from normal human omentum by using sequential enzymatic digestion followed by magnetic cell separation.

Any possible contamination with other cell types was excluded by uniform positive staining for FSP1, a calcium-binding protein of the S100 family that has been advocated as a sensitive and specific marker for fibroblasts (29).
In this respect, we have previously demonstrated its utility for identification and puri-fication of omentum-derived HPFB in culture (3).
In line with observations of Fries et al. (6), the subsets of HPFB with different Thy-1 expression differed also in cell morphology and cytoskeleton arrangement.

Interestingly, the proportions of Thy-1 ϩ and Thy-1 Ϫ HPFB freshly obtained from normal omentum varied somewhat across the donors, but on average the fraction of Thy-1 Ϫ cells was not significantly different from that of Thy-1 ϩ HPFB.
Exact contributions of various Thy-1 subsets to fibrogenesis appear to be organ specific.
We found that Thy-1 ϩ/Ϫ HPFB subsets differed in their ability to acquire features of scarproducing myofibroblasts.
Compared with Thy-1 Ϫ fibroblasts, Thy-1 ϩ cells displayed increased expression of ␣-SMA, collagen I, and TGF-␤1 and exhibited increased contractile and proliferative capacity.
These observations may suggest that Thy-1 ϩ HPFB are key effector cells in peritoneal fibrosis.
However, this may not be the case in other organs.

It has been demonstrated that normal lung fibroblasts are typically Thy-1 ϩ , whereas (myo)fibroblasts found in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and in mice with bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis are predominantly Thy-1 Ϫ (8).

In contrast, orbital fibroblasts from patients with Graves' ophthalmopathy were found to be mainly Thy-1 ϩ , and only these cells were capable of differentiating into myofibroblasts in response to TGF-␤ (18).
Similar properties were observed in Thy-1 ϩ , but not Thy-1 Ϫ , uterine fibroblasts (17).
Peritoneal fibrosis is clearly seen in adult patients undergoing PD, and it is thought to underlie the gradual loss of the peritoneal dialyzing capacity.
We therefore analyzed the presence of fibroblast subsets in the dialyzed peritoneum.
We chose to examine biopsies from children undergoing PD, as it minimized the potential impact on the peritoneal structure of aging and age-and lifestyle-related comorbidities.
In this respect, the majority of children suffered from diseases that were limited to the kidneys and/or the urinary tract.
Confirming our in vitro data, we detected the presence of FSP1 ϩ fibroblasts in normal omentum.
By contrast, we did not detect FSP1 ϩ cells in the parietal peritoneum, which was in line with earlier reports from both human (9) and animal (20) studies.
Our failure to detect FSP1 ϩ cells could be simply related to low numbers of biopsies examined and/or the scarcity of fibroblasts within the parietal peritoneum (25).
However, it is also possible that either resident fibroblasts in the parietal peritoneum do not express FSP1 or the omentum is a distinct niche for FSP1 ϩ fibroblasts.
On the other hand, FSP1 ϩ cells were detected occasionally in the parietal peritoneum of uremic and PD patients, and intriguingly, nearly all of them were Thy-1 ϩ .
In contrast to the rarity of FSP1 ϩ fibroblasts in the parietal peritoneum, FSP1 ϩ cells were considerably more conspicuous in the omentum.
Moreover, they increased significantly both in absolute numbers and in the fraction of Thy-1 ϩ cells in patients undergoing PD.
This increase indicates that PD therapy itself rather than associated uremia is responsible for the effect.
The potential contributing factors may include the exposure to dialysis fluids and/or the episodes of peritonitis.
It has been demonstrated that dialysate effluent collected from PD patients is capable of stimulating fibroblast proliferation (1,23).
This mitogenic potential significantly increases during peritonitis and can be attributed partially to a rise in intraperitoneal levels of inflammatory cytokines (1).
The expansion of FSP1 ϩ fibroblasts in the visceral peritoneum has also been documented in mice with fibrosis following experimental peritoneal injury (21).
Admittedly, we could not demonstrate the association between the incidence of peritonitis and the increased presence of Thy-1 ϩ /FSP1 ϩ fibroblasts.
This may be a result not only of a rather small number of biopsies examined but also of the infrequency of peritonitis episodes observed.
It would therefore be necessary to assess more samples as they accumulate in the registry.
A large number of biopsies would also be required to analyze the potential association between Thy-1 ϩ fibroblast expansion and peritoneal thickness and angiogenesis.
This is because both the thickness and the capillary density of the peritoneum in children increase normally from infancy to midchildhood but decline later (22).
Thus the time of PD initiation will impact the ultimate values registered in the course of therapy.
This aspect of peritoneal histology may be responsible for the fact that we did not see a clear increase in the thickness of the submesothelial compact zone and vessel density in our PD patients.
Moreover, it will be interesting to examine other peritoneal cells for Thy-1 expression.
In this respect, the presence of Thy-1 has recently been detected in free-floating mesothelial-like cells recovered from peritoneal lavages (14,15).
Similar to our observations, those cells highly expressed collagen I and ␣-SMA, which may indicate that profibrotic features associated with Thy-1 are not confined to a single cell type.
The potential clinical significance of our findings for PD remains to be established.

Although our experiments demonstrate a different potential of Thy-1 ϩ and Thy-1 Ϫ HPFB subsets to acquire a myofibroblast phenotype in vitro, further studies will be required to show their in vivo significance.
Such experiments could involve selective depletion of a given peritoneal fibroblast subpopulation in animals subjected to PD exposure.

In this respect, it has previously been demonstrated that mice engineered to have peritoneal FSP1 ϩ fibroblasts eliminated showed significantly reduced peritoneal thickening and angiogenesis following chlorhexidine gluconate infusion (21).

As the presence of Thy-1 on HPFB seems to signify their propensity for myofibroblast conversion, one can hypothesize that the proportion of Thy-1 ϩ cells makes the patients less or more susceptible to the development of fibrosis during PD.
If this is the case, assessment of Thy-1 ϩ HPFB may help to choose the optimal modality for patients requiring renal replacement therapy.
